Definitely worth revisiting in the future a few times for sure. Very pleasantly surprised.

This is a great movie. The writing is excellent. The dialogue is sharp, biting and entirely believable. The acting is superb. It is hard to believe how well this movie was cast; it's perfect. The relationships are developed well and so are each of the characters. There are moments of true drama and moments of pure comedic genius. The cinematography is awesome. It really sets the stage for the action of the film and provides incredible context for the story that unfolds. The music, too, enhanced the film and added to the depth of the story. The entirety of the film transports one into the world that the characters inhabit.Jeff Bridges performance is spot on. Even the minor characters manage to make a significant contribution to the story and enrich it.

reviews.review_title: Modern day Butch Cassidy & the Sundance Kid
reviews.content: I really enjoy this film never heard of it before I came across it by accident. . . glad I did. I love the Texas Rangers interaction with each other. Good acting two brothers rob banks to pay off Ranch before it goes into foreclosure. My only real gripe would be a small plot hole if the ranch can generate so much money what can't they use that to pay it off; I feel like that was never really explained. However, still a really enjoyable movie

reviews.review_title: A great movie that is not talked about enough
reviews.content: Hell or high water is a great film that doesn't get talked about enough. Although the films admitted slow pace for the first 40 minutes it used that time to develop characters. Speaking of the characters, the preformces in this film are stellar, and the world around them feels loved in and real. I agree that this film is incredibly inspired by the Coen brothers masterpiece "no country for old men" I feel like this has different very different motivations behind the characters. Not to mention the incredible cinematography. Not to touch on spoilers but the last 30 minutes in this film is some of my favorite moments of film in the last decade, but not just the least 30 more specifically the last five minutes which a conversation between two characters that floored me. If I am going to complain I think it has little rewatch value and the slow place in the beginning although important got a little boring. In conclusion a great film and is on Netflix right now if you want to watch it.

Highly entertaining!
When you've binged through enough Amazon or HBO shows...
Or tire of scrolling through endless Netflix or SVOD titles....
Then do a search for Hell or High Water! This is an exceptional movie. Acting is outstanding. Career performances from Chris Pine and Ben Foster in a profound brother narrative. Jeff Bridges is as excellent as ever. The story is equally powerful - a clever and creative take on the bank heist trope.Had some issues with direction. For instance, SPOILER: Would have liked to have better explained Tanner's (Ben Foster's) kill shot. It's central to his character and the story but it's left too vague for me. But that's real nitpicking for an otherwise almost flawless movie. You will not be disappointed renting this one.

Hell or High Water is a very very awesome movie. I enjoyed it so very much.I do see people comparing it to the movie 'no country for old men' and while it does have a similar feeling and setting to it, I believe it is ten times better than 'no country for old men' especially the ending.Hell or High Water hase everything a great Western movie needs, interesting characters (on the good and bad side) that you want to know more about, shootouts, chases, stand offs, saloons (in this case casinos and cafes) and of course Bank robberies. All that good old stuff very neatly wrapped up in a modern setting.Its just a great movie and should of gotten way more attention. Go watch it and soread it around, its awesome and you will wish you watched it sooner.

When I started to watch this movie, I wasn't sure what to expect. The opening sequence answered all those questions for me.I was sucked in immediately. The bank robbery was done so well. It felt realistic. No pointless explosions or unbelievable action sequences. The men doing the robberies immediately had you asking why they were doing this. The victims had realistic reactions; the feisty older woman, the scared teller, the old man with a gun and nothing to lose. The background of these two men come out shortly after the opening sequence. At that point I was all in. Everything just fits. The music matches up with the scenes. The choices for the roles were perfect. The colors and scenes make you feel like you are in a small town in the middle of nowhere out west.The action scene at the gas station had a punch that looked so realistic. I think scenes like that were why I enjoyed this movie so much. It felt real.The police officers story line is also very well done. It is a good cop, bad cop scenario, but not in the typical fashion. They make you almost not know who to root for, the robbers or the cops. It really is quite amazing how well the director and writer put you in an argument with yourself on who you want to come out the winner.There are so many great scenes in the movie. The father-son talk just before the final robbery. The scene with the officers talking, and it almost appears to dawn on them that the bank is almost the real enemy, the cause of so many of society's problems. The brothers wrestling while a country music song plays in the background.You knew how the last robbery was going to play out, yet it was done so well it was still perfect. It still had a twist that was unexpected. There was a death that shook you no matter what side you were rooting for. And the emotion that came immediately after was so passionate. I loved this movie. It is one of the best I have scene recently. It had a great story, one that had you rooting for all involved. You felt the pain and the struggle behind the robbers choices, the love they had for each other, the pain on how life played out. You also felt the the fight the officers had in wanting justice, the respect between them almost identical to the brothers.

This movie, and No Country for Old Men, remind me of my father. It's hard to explain to other people, but there's a streak that runs through these movies that encapsulates where he came from, and what he taught me.

Bank heist movie with a weak plot. Some of my favorite actors subjected me to intense boredom. The movie has some good moments but just watch this if you've run out of things to do. Too slow and predictable for me

I had high hopes & great expectations for this Oscar nominated flick but alas i was let down. I gave it a 7 and I think thats a fair rating. The story and film overall were good But the acting wasn't 'amazing' like some reviewers have stated ( many 10 ratings, cmon) nor a 10 in terms of overall greatness. Film was written well with a good storyline but i found some parts predictable. Both lead male roles did a good job portraying their Texas characters and the Texas landscape scenes were good in showing the vast empty land mass that is 'middle TX'. The ending was abrupt could of been better. Also, they never go into the Family story of why he's divorced, and why they only show a scene with 1 son and not the other was odd. I'm glad i rented it and not paid top dollar at the theater.

I have watched this movie over 90 times, and I can see it another 90 times. Why ? Because it cleverly shows a "Brothers Love" and a fathers love and the length he will go for them. I guess that makes me have to surrender my man card. I would do this same thing for my brothers if they were still living, and or my children, That is why this movie is special. If you have not watched this movie yet, You Must, as it is specially surprising. I am from Ohio by birth, but my heart beats for Texas "GOOD, BAD, or INDIFFERENT".
Love the theme. Love the sarcasm. Love the portrayal of west Texas

reviews.review_title: A Must-Watch Post-Western Epic About Two Brothers on Redemption's Trail
reviews.content: Two brothers of contrasting personalities set out for a similar goal, yet with differing motivations. They are: Toby (Chris Pine) and Tanner (Ben Foster) - the smart and the stupid - the cerebral and the primal; the brothers team up to rob some banks, consequently for another duo on the other side of the law - Marcus (Jeff Bridges) and Alberto (Gil Birmingham) - to chase after them for a run time of less than 1 hour and 50 minutes, of slow, but thrilling sequences delivered with witty, comedic and sometimes, sentimental dialogues without any lack of the gun-banging that is typical of westerns. However, this is no typical western; a cynical take on the genre, quite akin to the modern classic - No Country for Old Men - despite the differences in themes both represent, both were nurtured by the blissful hands of excellent cinematographers, capturing shots of sweeping landscapes and intense, nail-biting scenes - complementing the surprising, but fantastic performances from Pine and Foster and a resembling re-enactment of the legend himself, Bridge's famous roles, which is not a disadvantage to the film, especially not when paired with Birmingham's wry portrayal of an Indian character - who has to live through Marcus' constant spews of racist jokes, but not without Alberto flinging them back at him, which makes for some comedic back-and-forth-s that are much needed following somber moments. They share an interesting dynamic, however, the sentimentality of it all seeps through the brothers more often - not solely for the fact that they are brothers, even if it is a major contribution to my experience. I relished the subtlety of the performances, having them to transcend the film to an emotional family drama. Director David Mackenzie has been successful at creating this magnificent modern and realistic representation of the post-western genre that would not have been a likely possibility if well-reputed screenwriter, Taylor Sheridan wasn't at the helm of this script. Alas, it is a product assuredly deserving of its praise and your time.

The once peaceful lands of Western Texas have been surrendered into the control of the Texas Midlands Bank; forever dominating the people's wealth. A family's ranch is in jeopardy when tough circumstances meet brutal enforcement. Brothers, Toby and Tanner Howard must face the debt their mother leaves behind to keep their ranch. Beneath the land lies black gold which will end their poverty. Before they can progress, they must satisfy the bank's demands whether or not their methods are legal.Many and if not all of the best criminal films do not compare to the dry and dire nature that Hell or High Water depicts. The movie starves itself from the traditional happy-go-lucky plot leaving a crude and lawful journey to follow. In comparison, Escape from Alcatraz also depicts the dependability of family and the desire for change that drove the inmates to commit crimes. Hell or High Water challenges typical crime films with a different approach at success; sacrifice to break the shackles of poverty.
Generally, crime is one of the most difficult genre to depict in a film without excessively including fatuous events, characters, and plots. Many crime films obsess with including comedic and impractical scenarios that spoil the thrill of a crime film. Tom Cruise's
"American Made" was a true disappointment because the realistic events beneath the film held great potential; a common airline pilot recruited by the CIA in order to bring down the Medellin Cartel finds a new interest in the commission from smuggling drugs. Historically, the twisted events of Barry Seal's recruitment would appear fictional and that is exactly how it is depicted in the film. Likewise, Clint Eastwood's "Escape from Alcatraz" took a mushy approach representing the infamous convicts who escaped the inescapable. "Escape from Alcatraz" and "Hell or High Water" share the same grand scheme plot but only one of them captures the anticipation and excitement of the process. Furthermore, the advancement of the film industry allowed Hell or High Water to nail criminal films spot on by making the audience feel like they're in the moment. Somehow a sense of connection develops as you learn the principle of the film and witness the phenomenal acting.What makes Hell or High Water unique is the storyline that is told in a duel perspective. Throughout the film we see the Sheriff and his Deputy pursuing Toby and Tanner after they blow their cover. Generally, law enforcement is seen as a side or background aspect to a criminal film that appear when convenient. However in the virtually lawless land of Western Texas it's the Sheriff's personal conquest to glorify his last days with his badge. As for the Howard Brothers they have one goal in mind; keep their ranch and ensure a wealthy life for their family. The wholesome plot of the film makes Hell or High Water change how we see crime and the importance of family to some.Mackenzie, a relatively new director, makes a return since his last hit: "Starred Up," which follows a young offender through his timeline in custody. Prior to Hell or High Water or Starred Up, Mackenzie has only directed 6 other films none of which affiliate with crime. However all his films share the surreal realism of the stagecraft and portrayal of characters. CGI is praised for its tactility in portraying situations such as firefights, explosions, narcotics, and decent size land modifications. Yet CGI adds a cartoony aspect to a film that is supposed to feel live action. Mackenzie cleverly avoids using CGI making the film incredibly realistic. Gunfights in the film follow the stereotypes of Texan gun owners but in a way that adds to the story showing the feral turf of Western Texas. Additionally, the entire process of Toby and Tanner's heists is shown with minimal offscreen assumptions unlike other criminal films. In the end Hell or High Water does a spectacular job with its acting which makes me crave a sequel.Hell or High Water deserves a showtime for everyone even those with little interest. Ridded of cliche plots and CGI overkill, there is a laundry effect from the first to the last minute of the film. This film is remarkably a token of Mackenzie and a valid landmark for his 10th film. Rather than settling for big name faces and over advertised films experience crime without greed and glory instead for a greater purpose.

reviews.review_title: Forget Dallas, Houston, and Austin, This Movie is TEXAS!
reviews.content: That's it! You cannot get a full keg of Texas in a big city. Texas is hard and tough outside the city. Ft. Worth and San Antonio are still cities in Texas. But Texas is wide and natural. Hell Yeah to the writers, directors, and money men in an era when girls want to be boys, and boys don't know how to be men outside of the American West...On BOTH sides of the law. Thank you four years ago for keeping the culture based on the history alive even if it is fiction!

Great crime thriller and cast. 
A must see.
Jeff Bridges and Chris Pine are perfect. Realism done right in a neo-western heist movie with a lot to say about 21st century American capitalism.
A good production and story.  Jeff Bridges puts on one of his very best performances.
Wonderful actors, music and atmosphere.  Will watch again.

A brilliant neo-Western for the ages.

Director David Mackenzie's neo-Western crime drama Hell or High Water (2016) remains the best Western film of the past decade to me. His haunting shots, darker characterizations, brutal sudden violence, quiet tension, flawed heroes, and desperate villains ensure Hell or High Water is truly suspenseful. I continue to find Mackenzie's direction utterly riveting. Editor Jake Roberts' sleek cuts and steady pacing makes Hell or High Water's 102 minutes feel like a brief moment in time.

Writer Taylor Sheridan's story is interesting and original with deep character studies of these four main men. Sheridan's realistic writing gives each man believable motives for how they act and think besides their backstories that make each guy unique. I just keep thinking about how he separates men by their choices as every guy could potentially get desperate enough for cash to rob a bank in Sheridan's world. Hell or High Water's true grit brings the heat in the unforgiving red Sunlight of Texas.

Cinematographer Giles Nuttgens finds fascinating framing for cars speeding down the desolate highways or men facing each other down in tense personal close-up shots. Hell or High Water is full of vast wide expanses of oil fields, gas stations, casinos, banks, and diners. Nuttgens shoots these stunning wide shots with sweeping wide shots and visceral close-ups that hang onto these hardened men. You never know when they'll just make a snide remark or get up and fight a man like Chris Pine defending his brother at the gas station from an angsty metalhead in a green sports car. Hell or High Water makes Texas look desolate and lonely.

Chris Pine is amazing as neo-Western villain Toby Howard. His smart, cautious, charming, and suddenly vicious bank robber is fascinating. Hell or High Water is Chris Pine's best acting performance ever. I wish he got an Oscar for Best Actor for his gritty turn as Toby Howard. He's ready for a fight, but actively trying to avoid violence and confrontation, whether it's with security guards or ex-wives. Pine feels thoughtful with an inner burden and sorrow that he's carrying around with him. Marin Ireland is pretty and great as Pine's ex-wife Debbie Howard. Her worn down expressions imply how tired and sick of Toby's lack of child support payments or fathering his sons. Her scene is memorable.

Ben Foster is absolutely unhinged as the violent bank robber and ex-con Tanner Howard. He feels dangerous and ready to pounce on anyone who threatens him. He'll feel disdain for his mother, hate for his father, loyalty to his brother, and even charm a casino clerk girl. Foster delivers a fierce co-lead performance unlike any of his acting work since his ungodly gunslinger Charlie Parker in 3:10 to Yuma. His machine gun volley sets flying a hail of bullets on the highway to detract the local posse and state rangers hunting him. It's terrifying and exhilarating like Val Kilmer firing his machine gun in Heat during the legendary bank robbery sequence. His sniper rifle farewell scene is outstanding and fearsome.

Jeff Bridges is subtle in his understated supporting role as elderly Texas Ranger Marcus Hamilton about to retire. Bridges is funny with his smart wit, revolting with his casual racism, intelligent with his shrewd criminal insights, and cool with his fatal sniper fire and suspenseful final confrontation. Jeff Bridges was born to be in Westerns and totally earned his Oscar nomination for Hell or High Water. He should have won.

Gil Birmingham is sympathetic as Texas Ranger Alberto Parker, who has to take his partner's racist remarks against Native Americans in stride in order to hunt down bank robbers. He feels professional and by the book with an amiable attitude. You really care about this guy Alberto. Gil Birmingham should be appreciated more for Hell or High Water as I think he's often overlooked simply because Jeff Bridges just outshined him with a gripping character study right next to him. Gil's monologue about Native ancestry and banks taking money is fabulous and understated. You never suspect his ending is coming.

Amber Midthunder is wonderful in her cameo as the pretty shaken Vernon Bank teller who gets robbed. Midthunder is lovely in Hell or High Water and feels authentic with her quiet teller, nervous with every carefully chosen word. I'm overjoyed that since Hell or High Water, Amber Midthunder has starred in Legion and Prey. Screenplay author Taylor Sheridan himself cameos as the cowboy herding cattle away from a brushfire by the highway.

Katy Mixon is excellent as the Vernon waitress Jenny Ann, who flirts with Chris Pine and refuses to give Jeff Bridges her $200 tip as evidence because it is half of her mortgage. Dale Dickey is very nice as the blunt bank teller Elsie at the Howard brothers' first bank robbery in Hell or High Water. She tries talking them down in an unexpected dialogue. Kevin Rankin is good at the Texas Midlands bank account manager Billy Rayburn, who hates what the banks did to the Howard family.

Canadian actress Melanie Papalia is very sexy and sweet as the nameless hooker in the casino, who flirts with Chris Pine. Margaret Bowman is a riot as the rude T-Bone Waitress that does not take any flack. William Sterchi's agreeable bank manager Mr. Clauson is a fun bit. Alma Sisneros is very cute as the affectionate clerk who sleeps with Foster's Tanner.

Production designer Tom Duffield creates little diners, quaint small town bank layouts, and dusty wooden Texan homes. Art director Steve Cooper highlights barren plains with few grasses or animals except the metallic beast of oil rigs blackening the horizon. Set decorators Wilhelm Pfau, Scott Christopher Clark, James Duddy, and Chris Painter put financial papers in the banks, hearty steak meals in the diners, and just piles of clothes and beer in the houses to keep with that impoverished aesthetic. It all looks very grounded and realistic. Visual effects artists Dave Kim, Eric A. Kohler, and Dane Allan Smith create a massive fire in the distance, an explosive car bomb, furious gunfire, and a bloody sniper rifle headshot for Hell or High Water with total realism.

Composers Nick Cave and Warren Ellis create these charming and sullen folk tunes for Hell or High Water's sorrowful soundtrack. Nick Cave's lyrics bring a melancholy to his sonic Americana. I love the mournful tone to Cave and Ellis' Hell or High Water soundtrack. Sound designer Frank Gaeta lets the gunshot break the quiet small town silence with louds bursts of fire that echo out into noisy chaos.

Costume designers Malgosia Turzanska, Leila Heise, and Jane Day rustle up ranger uniforms, blue jeans as far as the eye can see, and every ten gallon cowboy hat in Texas for Hell or High Water's striking rustic fashion. All the shirts have nice designs or style for Chris Pine and Ben Foster's outfits, while Jeff Bridges and Gil Birmingham's ranger fits humorously match each other. Make-up artists Janeen Schreyer, Tarra D. Day, and Karla Muenze give each guy long, unkempt hair and gruff facial hair for a hardened look. The actors must all have grown their hair just for Hell or High Water's tough guy aesthetic.

In all, Hell or High Water is sad, exciting, and often funny with its brazen bank robbers and quirky rangers on the chase in a deadly game of cat and mouse. I simply adore this gritty neo-Western.
This movie hits all the right notes. Truly stunning performances by the entire cast. Great direction and solid offerings from the score and the cinematography.
Westerns are making a comeback!!!!!!!
Although there are dry spells from time to time, the film delivers in the action scenes and overall premise.
I have watched this movie numerous times and loved it everytime all over again.

Its okay its every cops and robber movie pretty much what youve seen before expect put together with different parts. Its nothing you havent seen before but it isnt executed poorly. Its an entertaining watch kind of a character piece.
Well done. Acting, pace, all good. Nothing absolutely blew me away, but a sold watch and happy I did. Good soundtrack to top it off.
Watching it once was not enough for me. Be sure to watch for Buck Taylor.  He must be a favorite of Taylor Sheridan.
Little new to offer here, though its script and acting is very good. Ultimately it falls flat because it's nod to "culture of poverty" theory is erroneous and stale.

A great neo-Western tale that still pits cops vs. robbers, but in this case, one of the robbers are motivated by more than a useless score. Hell or High Water explores the slowly rotting corpse of small town America and the changing tide of cops vs. robbers. Thematically speaking, this is a less effective No Country for Old Men. It is gripping in its action and dialogue and Jeff Bridges steals every scene he is in. I think a lot of people view Chris Pine as just another good looking actor guy, but I'm consistently impressed by him in the right roles, and man he's good in this one. It's pretty easy wax poetically about the headier aspects of this movie, but when it all comes down to it, it's just a cool movie: something that every good western needs to be.
Modern day cops and robbers story that's true to its cowboy-cinema legacy that (some how) avoids clichés.  Solid western yarn.

Masterpiece. Period. In the final scene: there is no clear good or bad guy. There's just two people.  
An absolutely retired, former bank robber who did what he did for all the right reasons; and a straight as an arrow, uncorrupt Texas Ranger. Both certain in there righteousness. Or they just don't care. Like gunslingers in the old west. Neither willing to back down. You watch this film and tell me different (that there's no clear good/bad guy in the final scene).
Excellent acting and story. I loved it
a great western with a great story and some phenomenal acting
Gritty, contextual, real. This is how excellent story-telling is done. You've been cheated if you haven't seen this.

5 years ago- Stylish and well acted, the film intelligently focuses on characters instead of nonstop action (although the action within is EXCELLENT). Jeff Bridges shines in the near retirement lawman archetype, bits of Rooster Cockburn shining through in his performance.
Hey, it's two brothers robbing banks in the middle of Texas. How could they go wrong with a premise like that?
Jeff Bridges shines as an old Texan ranger, but the protagonists and their motives are not good enough to get us rooting for them.
Great movie, very entertaining and exciting
We really enjoyed this movie.  The acting and sound track were good, the plot, theme, scenery and occasional comic relief kept us engaged.
excellent screenplay, acting, directing and running time.

was good for a crime movie.
This movie is solid!... Bridges and Pine stand out. I enjoyed it.

this was alright. i liked it well enough - it did leave me a bit underwhelmed, though. i enjoyed the overall story & everyone played their parts well, but they weren't good robbers. i was expecting a little smarter plan/execution on their part so when they were basically just running around with their heads cut off that kind of took away from the exciting heist aspect of the film for me. it almost leaves you asking "what was even the point?". is *IS* a decent watch, though, so i'd recommend it if you're interested - just don't have your hopes up too high.

The absolute way to do a modern-day western movie, "Hell or High Water" stands not only as one of the best westerns of the 21st century but as one of the best of all time. The film has a nice pacing throughout, never overwhelming or boring you as the story progresses and containing just the right amount of grit to make it a serious and moving drama while also containing just enough humour to make it an enjoyable ride throughout. The plot is also pretty realistic and ends up creating several thought-provoking themes. The characters were also done pretty well, mainly due to the incredible cast behind them. The soundtrack felt fitting for the whole atmosphere for the movie, and the cinematography was done extremely well to give it the Texan atmosphere. There is also a number of thrilling moments that keep you on the edge of your seat, and the third act provides a wild, action-filled conclusion. Its ending is also done very well and seems like the perfect close to a fantastic piece of 21st century western art. A great movie and one I can highly recommend to any moviegoer.

This was a lackluster movie. I bought into the high Rotten Tomatoes ratings and thought this was a sure hit. It wasn't that exciting and the pace was slow. There isn't anything too deep about this movie which was its intention. 

This is an action movie but there's really not much excitement about the plot. I missed the mark on this one by assuming it was good due to the reviews.
Excellent movie, from top to bottom! They don't get much better than this.
A pretty good heist film

An enjoyable movie. Well crafted.

There are a lot of people drinking the cool-aid on this one.  The story is relatively basic and unimaginative.  There is not much material to work with as can be acknowledged by the numerous songs played over no action and long conversations that amount to nothing of importance.  The characters are one dimensional and boring, and the "quest" is mind numbing. The acting was not supporting an otherwise well-written screenplay, it was saving an otherwise substandard one.

In Grapes of Wrath the Joads were forced to flee the dustbowl as the robber-baron machine did to them what their grand-folks had done to the Native-Americans. Well the Joads are back, and this time they got guns and a plan. A brilliant film which is stressful, cathartic, and at times darkly funny. A must watch.
Love this movie and i love it's ending. Had to watch it twice.

Hell or High Water is one of my favorite movies to come out in the last decade. Performances are amazing across the board, the character development is so well done. The ending is tragic and profound, this is the best neo-western I have ever seen.
Great version of the bank robbers with a heart.
Properly titled! The rodeo starts from the beginning and just gets more interesting. You're forced to sympathize with the two robbers and two cops to a point you don't know who to root for.

Hell or High Water (A+)
Never knew how well the format of a western could translate to a modern tale until now. This is the bar to try to reach when making modern day Western movies. This movie was thrilling, captivating, absolutely hilarious at moments, emotional, and action packed. It has a short runtime for a movie and it even felt shorter due to how much I was enjoying the movie. Chris Pine, Ben Foster, Jeff Bridges and Gil Birmingham all put on showstopping performances. The relationships between the two brothers of Pine and Foster as well as the two cops looking for them in Bridges and Birmingham are very well presented and you can feel the chemistry oozing of the screen.

I love how they showed the intentions these robbers had and that the film took time to delve deep into the lives of the robbers. By the end you are wanting all the characters to live and find resolutions. It isnt towards a climatic breaking point near the end until you can really say you hope they get caught and I love that about this film. I thought that the humor was really authentic and well placed in the film and while it was funny it didn't take from the overall drama the film had nor the story. 
I felt so many different pieces of this film worked and felt cohesive. I love how small scale and grounded this film felt and that the filmmakers took the time to make the story actually make sense. A lot of times you watch dramas and you can't relate and feel a disconnect from what is happening in some scenes. No scene in this film broke my connection to the characters. The thrilling aspects near the end of the film ramp it up to 11 and it's very moving and engaging.
Incredible flick. Great story love the writing.

Tex-ploitation. 4 Oscar nominations, really? I love Jeff Bridges as well as other actors in this film, but the portrayals were mere caricatures of Texan Redneck stereotypes. The only character I had any empathy for was Alberto (Gil Birmingham) who was mostly reacting to racial slurs from Marcus (Jeff Bridges). I guess you can't blame the actors when they're given such a mediocre script to work with. And such a predictable plot...Aaaagh.

At last a film worth watching. A smart story line made believable by direction that focuses on the characters and the conflict between them. Jeff Bridges turns in a measured performance as the gnarly Texas Ranger. A man out of his time and due for retirement, possessed by the long gone values of the west. Chris Pine is a surprise, he is a match for Bridges character. A young man driven to protect his family by turning to bank robbery. A morally conflicted, driven younger man he is a part of his world where Bridges is adrift. They share only a few minutes of screen time at the end of the film where each tries to justify their viewpoint and actions. Its a masterclass in dialogue and pacing. Every facet of this films production was crafted by professionals at the very top of their game

Short, sweet, and an absolute blast from start to finish with a superb script from Taylor Sheridan, David Mackenzie's thriller is a terrifically paced gem, starring Chris Pine and an always excellent Ben Foster as redneck brothers who team up to rob a series of banks in the Texas area, with Texas Ranger Jeff Bridges hot on their tale. This was, and remains, some of the most fun I've had in a cinema this decade, and the fact that it's a damn good film just makes it even more impressive.

This is a straightforward cops and robbers tale in rural modern Texas. It's good at showing why the robbers are robbing, and how the cops are pursuing, but beyond that it's a bit boring. It's not as compelling and tense as No Country for Old Men, nor as gleefully anarchist as Thelma and Louise or Bonnie and Clyde. Mostly it plays out as expected, and while it's not bad by any means it doesn't present anything particularly special.

Closest comparison: It's like What's Eating Gilbert Grape? by way of The Highwaymen (Netflix, 2019).

Hell or High Water is a neo-western heist movie about two brothers , portrayed by Chris Pine and Ben Foster, who are chased by two rangers, Jeff Bridges and his mate, Gil Birmingham while they rob rather small amounts of money from banks, in order to stop their land from being foreclosed. This movie was really fun. First off, Chris Pine and Ben Foster have so much chemistry, which is absolutely crucial for a movie like this. The acting overall is also great; I haven't really seen a weak link anywhere. The story is gripping enough to keep me interested throughout the entire movie, and the ending is as perfect as it could have been, in my opinion. Nothing extreme, but rather grounded and realisitc. You have two unlikeable characters trying to be stopped by other two unlikeable characters and somehow, you like all of them. This is when a movie really clinks for me, and this one sure did. Ben Foster's character is this hardened criminal, who has done it all, and acts without really thinking much of any consequences, and mostly does it for himself, when Chris Pine's character is the exact opposite of that, he has never killed someone, he never acts outside of what he has planned, and he does it for his family. In my opinion, this movie is close to being perfect.

A slow burner with hauntingly beautiful scenery.  It delivers fine performances from start to finish by all.  Jeff Bridges truly delivers as a seasoned lawman.  It is a tale of two very different brothers that share a common bond and two very different Texas rangers that share a common bond as well.  It's driven by its narrative, not by violent action.  Even though I found it to be sleepy at times, it's still a fine film I wouldn't hesitate to recommend.  "Hell or High Water" is a brutally honest expose about the lengths through which people go to demonstrate their fealty and the bonds that develop between men who share a similar endpoint.  If you long for shots of wide open spaces, conflict and resolution then this movie is ripe for the picking.

David MacKenzie and Taylor Sheridan have combined to make a taut, understated and riveting mystery movie in the guise of a modern Western.  Jeff Bridges, Chris Pine, Ben Foster and Gil Birmingham are excellent, with special kudos to Chris Pine for holding the screen with a muted and introspective performance.  There is a lot of sensitivity, humanity and even firm social commentary in this movie, and it anchors the story and creates a counterpoint to the violence and aggression that ultimately comes.

Hell or High Water takes the viewer to the far small town parts of Texas where old western society clashes with new society and morals. While the movie seemed lacking in its first act, it comes together for a beautiful finish filled with lessons in brotherhood, family, partnership and Texan society.

I throughly enjoyed this movie.  Chris Pine is without a doubt the best character in this movie.  It is very suspenseful and does a great job of keeping you hooked for the whole runtime.  The only problem I had with it was that there was nothing exceptional about the movie itself.

Although it is a fiction about criminals, in the drama of Hell or High Water it shows an authenticity that hurts and bothers. On the economic depression, the lack of opportunities and jobs. Jeff Bridges has made a career out of playing genial, likable slackers with a surprising amount of depth and hurt behind their seemingly complacent facades. I wouldn't call him my favorite actor, I think that the affection many have for his public persona cause them to overrate his abilities but he is right at home in a minimalist western like this one and his grizzled presence brings about a Larry McMurtry-esque tone. I wasn't totally infatuated with the film as I felt that it covers similar ground to many other westerns that go deeper in their exploration of poverty's effect on families and the importance of father figures. Fans of the genre should rejoice in finding a film that actually has something to say as opposed to The Magnificent Seven (2016).

Downtrodden Texan Toby Howard, Chris Pine, is divorced from his wife Debbie, Marin Ireland, and estranged from his children. He wants to ensure that they will be financially secure in the future and wants to continue to own the ranch that his mother left him after her death but a mortgage from a cruel local bank makes this difficult. In order to finance his ambitions he teams up with his loose cannon brother Tanner, Ben Foster, to carry out robberies of various local banks and later launder their money through a casino before depositing the money in the bank that plans to take their ranch away from them. Chasing them is aging Ranger Marcus Hamilton, Jeff Bridges, who keeps up a friendly rapport with his partner Alberto Parker, Gil Birmingham, while considering his impending retirement and ability to do his job successfully. Tanner's volatile personality leaves the brothers vulnerable and even as they begin to pay off their debts they have serious doubts about their ability to stay alive.

Where the film excels is in capturing the poverty of the area subtly as it is never overplayed but there is a desperation to all of the characters that is driven by their economic concerns. Director David Mackenzie allows the camera to linger on tagging around the various small towns that the brothers pass through that gives the sense that people there have nothing to live for and no real way to express their outrage. For the brothers we understand that this ranch is what little they have left and to them the bank, an institution that could take their only remaining asset away from them, is a major enemy. The inhabitants of these small Texan towns also seem wary of institutions as they are not forthcoming with information about the robbers for the police. In one fascinating scene a sweet waitress refuses to give up $200 given to her by the robbers because it is the only thing that will allow her to pay her mortgage. We are left to imagine how her and countless other struggling men and women get by without miraculous donations such as this one.

There is also the usual infatuation with the big skies and flat plains of the Texan landscape and while the film never quite reaches the level of Hud (1963) in how beautifully open and natural the area is at night Giles Nuttgens tries his hardest to imitate James Wong Howe. Foster and Pine give fine performances as two brothers trying to make their way in the world as they don't over do the accents, i.e. Kenneth Branagh in The Gingerbread Man (1998), and imbue their characters with varying degrees of intensity. Foster is known at this point for his manic performances as men angry at the world whether it be in Alpha Dog (2007) or Ain't Them Bodies Saints (2013) and he replicates his act to good effect here as he is believably unhinged. Pine was more of a question mark heading into the film as he is best known for his role in Star Trek (2009) and had not been known as an actor of dramatic heft by this point. He is a compelling lead as while he might be a little too glamorous to be believable in the role he is restrained and contemplative enough to successfully play off of his showy counterparts.

The film is worth a watch because while it may not necessarily have spoken to me that strongly because I don't love westerns it boasts more than the average genre film.
It was alright, not great. Lots of western montages and a plot managed. It didn't leave much of a feeling in me when all was said and done.
Well written and acted heist thriller.
A slow paced movie that draws you in and delivers. My favorite movie ever.
Great movie, watched it multiple times.

A modern-day West Texas noir that cuts out the special effects for real drama.

As a West Texas native, I'm surprised at how close the scenery hits to home. The setting is as real as it can get. I cannot begin to start on the number of towns I've visited that resembled the ones in this film. But I digress.

The characters themselves I enjoyed. There are no good guys in this film. Everyone has their motivations and reasons for doing the things they do. This is a modern Wild West cops and robbers chase.

5/5. Worth it and will see it again. Shame that this movie did not receive the marketing that it deserves.

A modern western that is smart in its approach to a slow building narrative. Taylor Sheridan seems to be an expert in this genre, always keeping a balance of interesting characters and rough landscapes that further add to the troubles of living in America. Foster and Bridges really own their roles and the final 30 minutes are absolutely exhilarating.

I thought this movie was well made, but really didn't do much different from other outlaw bank robber movies. I thought Ben Foster was amazing, but Chris Pine and Jeff Bridges seemed to have played characters like this before. I really liked the scene where Jeff Bridges' character confronts Chris Pine's character on the farm in the end, it was full of tension and adrenaline, but other than that this movie was a little bland.
If I could ever make a movie I would badly want it to be just like this one.

With all the talent on board in this movie it was hard not to get excited for this one but it still managed to blow me away with its excellent acting, screenplay, directing, and cinematography.  A return to what made westerns such a great genre. 9/10

I was disappointed by how uneventful this movie was. I enjoy a good heist film and I am a huge fan of the western genre. But this movie had none of the charm that makes a good heist film, nor did it have the wit that makes a good western. I did like a couple of the characters like Jeff Bridges' Marcus Hamilton who is the police officer looking for the brothers. Despite that, the film felt like it was lacking in structure. I didn't feel for any of the characters during the sad scenes, I didn't feel excited during the action scenes, and by the end I felt let down.
Just a good ole cops and robbers story.

Really loved the West Texas setting here, it was beautifully shot. Acting was excellent, love seeing Jeff Bridges play a Texas Ranger. Pine and Foster are great in the lead roles as brothers on the run after robbing from a chain of small time banks. Essentially it's a modern day Western, great watch.
Hell or High Water is the epitome of neo-western films in the 21st century.
Loved this movie, same feel as "No country for old men"
The latter half of Hell or High Water compensates for some of the action and emotions that the first half may have been slightly missing, and so much more.
Decent flick worth watching. There is no way the ending makes any sense though.

351. Hell or High Water. Have you ever wondered what a classic western style story would be like filmed today without much done to update the script? No, me either, until I realized that's exactly what I was watching... Story about two bank robbing brothers, Tanner and Toby Howard, raising enough cash to keep the bad bank man from taking the farm. Ya see, they struck oil on that land, not much, but enough to get by. Toby is the smart one, doing bad things for good reasons. Tanner is the wild card, doing bad things just to do bad things, but deep down, doing it for his brother! But coming up quick behind them is the law, Texas Ranger kinda law!! The old sheriff, Marcus Hamilton, just about to retire, and through pretty much intuition alone ends up in the right places at the right times, and with Marcus his Native American partner, Alberto, who is assaulted by the racist humor of the sheriff all day, but deep down, there's a bromance going on! And as Tanner and Toby continue their bank robbing ways, Tanner gets a little cocky takes on a bank full of people, shots fired, they barely escape with their lives, the townsfolk round up an armed posse to go after them chasing them up the road, but right around the corner is the sheriff, because deep down he knew where those pesky Howard boys were gonna strike next leading up to the ultimate showdown between the Texas Rangers and a couple of law breaking cowboys!! So this takes place in modern day, but it had the classic western set up. So if you're looking for a modern day western, go for it, looking for Heat, or Point Break, i'd say probably not. Filmbufftim on FB.
It's beautifully made. Just work on your pacing.

In a desperate struggle between two good ol' boys trying to save their farm from the bank, this modern-day western captures West Texas and the cowboy code of honor. Jeff Bridges plays The Law like the fat, crusty old man he has become. Equal parts thriller and tragedy, ultimately we all end up sad about how nothing of the romance of the old west has been able to survive the forces of greed that defile everything they touch.

Hell or High Water is a snapshot on a post-recession Texas through the setup of a traditional bank robber story. Chris Pine ditches his movie star image for a quiet, reserved performance as a run down Texan trying to do right by his family and Ben Foster is the reckless loose cannon who he calls his brother. Jeff Bridges is basically playing himself, but that works to great effect. Very good, well paced with good cinematography and great dialogue.
Terrific story. Great lead performances. The script and stars steal the show. Feels like a throwback to the 70s.

Gotta say, Jeff Bridges turns in an outstanding performance.  I'm a West Texas native and I can count so many Texas sheriffs, Rangers, DPS, city and county cops who are exactly like him.  Not a fan of Ben Foster.   He just didn't fit the role.  Nor did Chris Pine.  I thought it was a good twist on an old theme, but it felt and looked jumpy, as if there was too much to fit into a short time frame.  As the plot unfolds, we catch a glimpse of why the brothers are robbing banks, but it just didn't catch me in a way I thought it would.  The ending was hacky.  I doubt seriously the Ranger could have made that shot from the position he was in.  And the very end, the confrontation, over done I think.  I understand some lawmen can't let go of the job, and I understand the motive of the Jeff Bridges character of wanting revenge for the death of his partner, however, the shooting on the mountain was a bit too cut and dried, and the confrontation at the end seem strained and forced at best.  At worst, It's a convenient vehicle for the viewer to guess what may or may not happen next.
So refreshing to see a movie with both Inteligent police and criminals
Great performances from Ben Foster and Chris Pine, a movie about the bond of brotherhood with a western feel to it.  Straight-forward plot lifted by fantastic writing and sure-handed directing

What I like to call a western with cars, or I guess as most people call it a neo-western.  One of the best I've ever seen if I'm being honest too.  I'm not much of a fan of westerns typically, but there's an energy to Hell or High Water that kept me totally engaged.  That's not to see it betrays it's genre for an action movie trope or something, it's still moody and atmospheric in it's western tropes, it's more in the spirit of the film, the heartbeat of the film that the energy comes through more than any action on screen.  There are no real heroes, no real villains, and a grim and ugly look that is still beautiful in every frame.  I really liked it.

Brilliant Brilliant movie, with top notch acting and story. Will be looked backnon in years as over looked and a masterpiece. Jeff Bridges and Ben Foster steal the show but the best part of this movie is Chris Pine and his underrated talent!
One of the fest films of the year
Happy ending, worth watching.
A superb film, front to back. Grade-A performances, slick directing, and an air-tight script filled with wit, humor, and authenticity.

Reminiscent of "No Country For Old Men" with Marcus (Jeff Bridges) coming out of retirement to track down a series of bank robberies committed by 2 brothers of  Toby(Chris Pine) and Tanner (Ben Foster) .

David Mackenzie's outlaws-on-the-run saga concerns two brothers (Chris Pine and Ben Foster) who embark on a bank-robbing spree in order to raise enough money to save their family farm from foreclosure, a conceit that lends the film a piercing timeliness. Nonetheless, the true power of this rugged genre effort comes from its stars and its attention to both atmosphere and character detail. As yin-yang siblings compelled to embark upon their mission by need, fury, and inherent recklessness, Pine and Foster share a compelling chemistry. And they're complemented in the charisma department by the always great Jeff Bridges. As the just-about-to-retire sheriff hot on their trail, Bridges delivers one of his finest performances, radiating both wit and regret as an old-school relic cop. This film had some of the best performances of the entire year. Definitely one of my favorites of 2016.
I don't usually like movies of this genre, but this was very entertaining! I love a good movie that doesn't bore me.
I wish it was 3 hours long, that's how much I enjoyed this great work or story telling
In just 97 minutes Hell Or High Water is a smart, intense and well acted heist thriller that revitalizes the western genre for a new generation.

The best movie of its type since No Country for Old Men or True Grit (the remake). I like the part when Chris Pine tells Jeff Bridges that poverty is like a disease that spreads from generation to generation. Because that's what this movie is about.
best movie of 2016 hands down

Sensational acting & beautifully shot, Hell or High Water portrays a narrative seen and hard far too frequently; good people doing bad things, because bad things have been done to good people. 

Pine and Bridges steal the show, as their game of cops and robbers poetically traverses the lone star state. 

The premise is straight forward (foreclosure -> robbery -> car chase) but the acting, script, sub plots & swathes of emotion staged throughout, make it a stand out film in an era of exceptional cinema.  

If adventure, revenge, justice, quips and 21st century wild west are your things, than I really don't need to say anymore, because it truly doesn't get much better than this.

Strengths: The relationship between the brothers is the thing that this film excels the most. Chris Pine (Toby Howard) gives what is arguably the best performance of his career. He's likable and plays well off his brother. Ben Foster (Tanner Howard) is almost unrecognizable as his ex-con brother. He might be the show stealer, playing an unhinged man who is hell bent on helping his brother, even if it means sacrificing himself. Jeff Bridges (Marcus Hamilton) is his usual great self. There's a sense that he's kind of a jerk, but there's heart behind what he does. The bank robbery scenes are well done without going over the top. The tense scenes, like Toby getting stopped at a roadblock or his conversation with Marcus at the end of the film are both brilliantly handled. There's not a lot of effects used, but when we do get them, it looks great. There's a specific gunshot that looks phenomenal late in the movie. The direction is top notch and the script allows for some deep moments among the characters.

Weaknesses: The plot is ultimately very simple and straightforward. It's not a flat out bad thing, but it shines a light on the fact that this movie could mean more if things were laid out a bit differently. Along with that, some of the characters are kind of stereotypical and not fully fleshed out. We have the father trying to do right by his kids, the raging ex-con, etc. Another issue is some of the pacing. Points of the movie seem to drag. 

Overall: Once you get past some pacing problems and some of the simple stuff, you find yourself watching a well-acted, engaging film with some great emotional beats.

Hell or High Water is one of the best crime dramas I’ve seen in recent years. The movie has a decent amount of action, character development, and drama. It’s perfectly balanced. The script is great and Jeff Bridges gives an Oscar worthy performance. It’s a very enjoyable film and easily one worth watching again. It’s one of the best movies of the year.

I'm a sucker for a good, modern-day western. Hell or High Water, however, is simply mediocre.

The plot is excruciatingly dull. Tanner (Ben Foster) and Toby (Chris Pine) need to rob banks to steal money to pay off the old farmhouse so that Toby can give it to his family... or something? And I guess paying the bank off with their own money would make it more interesting? I don't know. It's never even clear who planned this whole fiasco.

The characters aren't much better. Tanner and Toby are cardboard cutouts painted with stereotypes. Marcus Hamilton (Jeff Bridges) is nothing more than a rehash of every sheriff in every Western ever filmed. Except with more mumbling. The only remotely interesting character was Alberto Parker (Gil Birmingham), and he is criminally underdeveloped and underutilized.

Speaking of Alberto - his death is unearned and feels cruel. Maybe that was the intention, but it leaves the viewer with a bad taste. The fact that Marcus, who spent the entire movie mumbling racist jokes at his good-natured partner, hardly even seems phased makes the circumstance even worse.

The best part of Hell or High Water is the commentary on the changing way of life and how that affects people in the poorer parts of the United States. Toby has an excellent quote towards the end of the movie about how being poor is like a disease, and it infects and corrupts generations of people.

Overall, Hell or High Water is a film with good ideas and intentions but, ultimately, falls flat on the execution and presentation.

A thrilling, intense ride. 

Texas brothers--Toby (Chris Pine), and Tanner (Ben Foster), come together after years divided to rob branches of the bank threatening to foreclose on their family land. For them, the hold-ups are just part of a last-ditch scheme to take back a future that seemed to have been stolen from under them. Justice seems to be theirs, until they find themselves on the radar of Texas Ranger, Marcus (Jeff Bridges) looking for one last grand pursuit on the eve of his retirement, and his half-Comanche partner, Alberto (Gil Birmingham). As the brothers plot a final bank heist to complete their scheme, and with the Rangers on their heels, a showdown looms at the crossroads where the values of the Old and New West murderously collide.

This was an interesting film. It has been two years since this movie has come out and considering it garnered a lot of buzz at the Oscars (which I don't care about), I'm surprised it took me this long to watch it. It's just been sitting on my shelf for a while now and just until recently, I hadn't plopped it into my Xbox One. Then, my friend came over and we decided to watch "Hell or High Water" on one of our many movie nights. It was a really solid ride overall, even if I may not have fully been able to appreciate it the first watch-through. 

One thing fantastic about this film was the talent. Chris Pine and Ben Foster really took charge and put on great performances in this film. Their overall talent and ability to work together gave something very interesting. However, am I the only one who saw them and thought of Sam and Dean Winchester? I don't know why, as they didn't necessarily match those same personas, but I just thought of those two. Anyways, the characters they played were characters with opposing personalities, which gave them a lot of clash, but a lot of work well also. 

Overall, I felt like this movie was just really tense. It wasn't necessarily this adrenaline pumping thing, nor was it slow. It was in the middle, setting up its scenes with these really deep, intellectual conversations and moments. Especially the ending, I really enjoyed a lot of the moments in this film that spoke so much without necessarily saying a lot. 

In the end, "Hell or High Water" was a solid film with some great moments. It had great cinematography, great acting, solid characters, and a good story ark. Overall, a solid watch.

This is just the best! The script, the acting, the cinematography, that soundtrack. The themes that paint the narrative range from right to conceal and carry, to the dichotomy of big city Wall Street to small town Main Street. Posing questions but allowing the audience to come up with there own answers. I think 10 different people could see the movie 10 different ways and all enjoy it.

It's, far and away, Chris Pine's best performance as a leading role.  All of the characters are uniquely human with these wonderful lines of ambiguity. Sure, Pine robs banks, but he is in touch with his morality and even burdened with guilt, and Ben Foster is most definitely a villain but he has such love for his brother. And Jeff Bridges! God love the good ole cowboy hat wearing, mushy-mouthed Jeff Bridges. Fully devoted to and talented at his job but again, not without his own flaws.  His relationship with his partner, Gil Birmingham, is one of my favorite aspects of the film, and its culmination turns the grumpy "I'm too old for this shit" trope on its ears. They get along but probably wouldn't if they weren't partners. Bridges is a bit difficult to be around, but he shows love and respect in a certain way, and it's the only way that he knows how.  Even the superb performances of the bit players gives the setting such an authenticity. Having grown up in Texas I feel like I've met many of the supporting characters (for better or worse).

Hell or High Water also makes such great use of the emptiness of west Texas. Everything is timed and paced and laid out so well that there are periods of time that highlight how boring open space can be, then jolts you to life with these crime scenes that are reminiscent of Michael Mann's Heat.
Best Western movie ever. Not that I watch a lot, but sure is one of the best

West Texas seems a burnt out place in this moody thriller (of sorts) from writer Taylor Sheridan and director David Mackenzie. The soundtrack by Warren Ellis and Nick Cave adds dramatically to the effect alongside a well-chosen selection of country twang that fits the West Texas setting.   The plot unfolds slowly with an easy-going air of simplicity.  Two brothers (Ben Foster and Chris Pine) are robbing banks to raise some money for an unknown reason. Two Texas Rangers are tracking them (Gil Birmingham and Jeff Bridges).  The film takes the time to show us their relationships in enough detail so that we see their differing personalities.  But the overall effect is of patient and economic storytelling. Director David Mackenzie (although a Brit) captures the despondent ethos of the local area, where banks and their greed have helped to create and perpetuate poverty and anger.  Eventually, we find out the motivation for the younger brother (Pine), even as we realise that the older brother (Foster) is a psychopath.  Bridges and Birmingham don't have too much to do except to exchange (loving) insults.  Yet, the result is watchable and rewarding on a sort of primeval level, even if the film doesn't have too much to say didactically. (An interview with the director and cast suggests they were trying to present reality as ambiguous).  In the end, you probably wouldn't want to live there but it's a pleasure to absorb the mood for a couple of hours.

Excellent cross between a western and a bank robbery movie, with great performances by Chris Pine and Jeff Bridges.  The film is in someways very traditional but manages not to be cliche.  All around an engaging and riveting film.

The second of the trilogy by Taylor Sheridan.  The first Sicario, this second, and Wind River third.  His style is creating a modern western, and he finds great actors to portray his well thought out characters.  Enjoyed the scenery and character development.

In West Texas, divorced father Toby Howard (Chris Pine) and his ex-con brother Tanner (Ben Foster) carry out early morning robberies of two branches of the Texas Midlands Bank. Though the robberies are well-planned, Tanner's wild nature leads to him to take unnecessary risks, frustrating Toby. Two Texas Rangers, Marcus Hamilton (Jeff Bridges) and Alberto Parker (Gil Birmingham), are on the case. Hamilton, who is close to retirement, quickly determines the brothers' methods and personalities. Meanwhile, Tanner robs another bank while Toby unknowingly waits at a nearby diner. They take the stolen money to an Indian casino in Oklahoma to be laundered. They exchange the stolen bills for chips, some of which Tanner uses to gamble. Toby then has the casino convert them into a check made out to the Texas Midlands Bank - the same bank they robbed. With untraceable funds and gambling as a cover for how they were acquired, the brothers head back to Texas.
It is revealed that the brothers' mother died recently, leaving their ranch in debt due to a reverse mortgage provided by the Texas Midlands Bank. If the debt is not paid off in a few days, the ranch will be foreclosed. Toby is determined to pay off the mortgage to ensure a comfortable life for his estranged sons because oil has recently been discovered on their land. They rob Texas Midlands as a form of frontier justice. Hamilton and Parker has to anticipate the next move of the thieves to catche them...

"Hell or High Water" received critical acclaim, with many praising the film as revitalizing the western genre. Rotten Tomatoes consensus reads, "Hell or High Water offers a solidly crafted, well-acted Western heist thriller that eschews mindless gunplay in favor of confident pacing and full-bodied characters. Richard Roeper of the Chicago Sun Times gave the film four out of four stars, saying, "In ways large and small, Hell or High Water is a movie so beautiful and harsh and elegiac and knowing, the moment it was over was the moment I wanted to see it again." IGN reviewer Samantha Ladwig gave the film a 9/10, saying "Hell or High Water surprises with its complex narrative, stuns with its cinematography, and makes up for this summer's shortcomings." Tom Stempel of Creative Screenwriting praised Hell or High Water as "a fresh, smart, bank robbery-character study and one of the best screenplays so far this year." The film premiered at the Un Certain Regard section of the 2016 Cannes Film Festival on May 16, 2016, and was theatrically released in the United States on August 12, 2016. It received critical acclaim and grossed $37 million. The American Film Institute selected it as one of its ten Movies of the Year, and it was nominated for numerous awards, including four Oscar nominations at the 89th Academy Awards: Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor (Bridges), Best Original Screenplay and Best Film Editing. It also received Golden Globe nominations for Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor for Bridges and Best Screenplay.

"Hell or High Water" is really nicely directed by David Mackenzie with great cinematography and editing, we get great performances from Pine and Foster as the leads, Bridges is however doing the same mumbling Texan type he did in "True Grit" and "R.I.P.D." which is getting a bit tiresome as he is such a versatile great actor. The plotline with the "bad guys" (the bank in this case) and the "good guys" (Howard and his brother trying to save their childhood home ranch) is hardly unique, but the build up between the protagonists and the antagonists is the interesting part creating empathy and sympathy for the characters on both sides of the story. I like as well the homage to the western genre and it being a modern time western. And I also like the quite slow pacing that sometimes explode in mayhem and violence.

The story, performances, direction, and cinematography are all perfect in this movie.  It is a perfect blend of action, humor, and melancholy.  The film can be viewed as a great modern Western and bank-heist movie.  But at its heart, it is an exploration of the complex theme of What does love for family mean, even in the context of guilt and neglect?  The characters are complex and real, and just fascinating and fun to watch.  I don't see any standout performances, because they are all great!

(94/100)
I love these new Modern Westerns. Hell or High Water is such a good movie. One of my favorites of 2016.

Hell Or High Water

The problem in a character driven movie is that if it ain't interesting, gripping or cognitive the feature starts to fade off slowly and the only thing remains is the ticking clock which takes too much of its time to finish of what was started. David Mackenzie is no short on execution but doesn't seek attention and fails to utilize the script by Taylor Sheridan which frankly had more potential than it was projected. Jeff Bridges is straight out amazing along with a great cast like Chris Pine and Ben Foster who are giving their all in. Hell Or High Water is not the cure, its the disease that even though slowly but surely is taking away the essence (brilliant screenplay, stellar performances and even background score) out of it.

Hell or High Water is one  of the most overrated movies of 2017. If you want to watch this movie, just know that you can count with a lot of boredom combined with predictable and already seen scenes. Unnecessary.
I think this is my favourite heist movie ever. Such a perfect combination of western sound and interesting characters.

A modern American bank heist film following two brothers who are robbing a specifc Texan bank's branches with Texas Rangers in hot pursuit. 

I admire the director's reluctance to focus on car chases and shoot-outs, which must have been enticing in a heist film. Instead of the obvious he allows the actors to create their own tension by delving slowly deeper and deeper into the pressing question: Why on earth are they risking so much to rob this bank of small bills? Small, seemingly insignificant moments become monumental decisions. A brunch at a diner becomes a fork in the road when one of the brothers notices a branch of their despised bank across the road. Will they or won't they try to rob it in broad daylight? 

The soundtrack, mostly country/rock ballads and guitar gems adds considerably to the experience. If you like this one check out Terrance Mallick's "Badlands".

Fantastic neo-western with stellar acting performances, especially by Jeff Bridges. Each of his scenes is an absolute delight, from the hilarious humorous parts to the darker second half. The plot, dialogs and cinematography complete the engaging near-perfect picture of bank robbing and law-enforcement in Texas. Probably the most Texan film ever, I imagine.
This Western is less about gun-fighting and more about complex human beings. The acting is phenomenal and the pace is just right,

Beautifully shot capturing both the desolation as well as the sprawling, rugged beauty of some of the poorer areas in Texas, 'Hell or High Water' is realistically written with rich characters and a story that blurs the line between right and wrong, capturing the essence of a Western where, sometimes, a man's just gotta do what a man's gotta do. A spattering of humour here and there, as well as spot-on performances from all involved provides the icing on the cake making this one hell of an entertaining film.

Great scenery, great actors, but the entire premise was hilariously bad.

This is a pretty captivating movie that does a great job of showing just what life is like in west Texas. I love Jeff Bridges in this, the way he speaks and his interplay with his fellow ranger. The scene at the T-Bone Steak place is great. The one detraction for me that kept me from liking it more is the issue of motivation. At the end I said "wait, why did they rob these banks again?" Their motivation to me was a little overcomplicated and unsatisfying. This is definitely a movie worth seeking out though.

Well-paced and truthful to the experience of West Texas, "Hell of High Water" is a testament to desolation, loyalty, family, property, and above all, the mark of all true Westerns, ethical action. And there are moments of tense action and moments of thoughtful ethical questioning that carry the film, even when some of its other motifs drag into shallower ends of the spectrum. While you may not leave the movie in deep contemplative thought, it's hard to knock a story that equates bank robbers and bank founders, colonial powers with financial institutions.

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, is it true that someone told us to go to Hell?

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) Only if Hell is a town in West Texas. Let s recap:

SCOTT: We meet the Howard brothers, a pair of modern-day cowboys who have taken to robbing banks in west Texas. Toby (Chris Pine) is the younger brother, and Tanner (Ben Foster) is the older brother who has recently been released from prison. On their tail is a pair of Texas Rangers who want to put an end to the brothers  crime spree. The head Ranger is Marcus Hamilton (Jeff Bridges) who is nearing retirement, and Alberto Parker (Gil Birmingham), a Native American who somehow tolerates Hamilton s racist banter.

GREG: The brothers have a scheme to rob the Midland Bank of enough cash to pay off the debts of their mother s reverse-mortgaged ranch. The brothers are following Toby s plan, but Tanner is a loose cannon and strays from the plan. This leaves enough clues for Hamilton and Parker to predict their next heist. It s a game of cat and mouse as the Rangers close in on the brothers in a tight spiral.

SCOTT: Greg, I ll just come right out and say it. Hell or High Water is one of the best movies of 2016. How refreshing it is for a film released in August to boast a rich and nuanced screenplay coupled with memorable and multidimensional characters. This movie held me in rapture, from the opening scene to the closing scene. The film opens with a bank robbery but in the background stands a church with three prominent crosses on the wall, foreshadowing the later deaths of three of this film s main characters. In the concluding scene, Hamilton moves away from the camera while the camera hits the dirt, suggesting that he is, in fact, the third casualty. This movie compels you to see things and to see people at a deeper level, a human level. The four main characters have an unusual strength and depth to them, a multi-dimensionality that I havent seen in the movies in years. Jeff Bridges didn t just portray a Texas Ranger; he was that Ranger. It s Oscar time for him, for sure. Every character inhabiting this film came alive on the big screen, made me laugh, made me cry, or repulsed me. The film is a true gem, a throwback to a bygone era of filmmaking when character development mattered.

GREG: Part of the pleasure of this story is that it s a mystery. The mystery is: why are these cowboys robbing these banks? We re fed clues incrementally, just as the Texas Rangers discover them. So, despite the fact that we re following the brothers closely, we don t know the reasons why until nearly the third act. This is a great anti-villain story cut from the same cloth as Bonnie and Clyde and The Sting. The lead characters are villainous as they are on the moral high ground. In our book Reel Heroes & Villains we talk about anti-heroes. They take on the characteristics of villains but are the characters we are rooting for. Contrariwise, the Texas Rangers are anti-villains. That is, they are the good guys in the story, but are the antagonists for the leads. It s a great structure. But what makes this film work, more than anything else, is the depth of the characters portrayed. I had to do a double-take because I thought this might have been a Coen Brothers or Weinstein film (both producers of great character-based films). But no, this one was penned by veteran television writer Taylor Sheridan (Veronica Mars and Sons of Anarchy). I was blown away by the combination of action, suspense, and great character detail.

SCOTT: You re so right, Greg. The hero s journeys are nontraditional, with the Howards voluntarily moving into the dangerous unfamiliar world while pulling the Rangers in with them. Tanner performs the ultimate (anti-) heroic act of sacrificing himself for the success of the mission, and Alberto does the ultimate heroic act of sacrificing himself, albeit involuntarily, for the success of the Rangers  mission. We have parallel anti-hero and hero stories with no real transformation, only adaptation to circumstances -- which can be considered a type of transformative adjustment heroes need for success. The mentoring is equally rich and unconventional. Older brother Tanner takes the physical lead role in being badass and anti-heroic, but it is his younger brother Toby who masterminds the entire caper. Among the Rangers, it is Marcus who mentors Alberto in the dress code and in doing detective work, but in the end it is Alberto s quiet dignity that exerts a great emotional impact on Marcus. Toby also plays an important mentoring role with his older son -- or, rather, an anti-mentoring role, as Toby cautions his son not to be like him. While the Rangers serve as anti-villain characters, it s also pretty clear that the biggest villain in this story is the institution of banking. In our most recent book we discuss how institutions can take on villainous roles. Usually these institutions are societal scourges such as racism or sexism. In this film the villainous institution is clearly the financial industry that conspires to squeeze every cent out of society s most innocent and vulnerable people. In doing their noble anti-villainous work, the Rangers encounter obstacles in the form of popular disdain for the banks that are being robbed. The robbers, in effect, take on folk-hero status. So the villain in this story, the banking industry, ends up hindering the anti-villains  ability to carry out their mission while having a slightly facilitative effect for the anti-hero brothers. In all it s a fascinating triad of anti-heroes, anti-villains, and institutional villain.

GREG: Hell or High Water is a cleverly draw tail of modern-day anti-heroes. Everything in this film is excellent: the acting, the cinematography, the story, even the scenery. Often in the movies I m distracted by the execution of the  seams  of the standard plot points. But Hell kept me in suspense with it s unspoken mystery of why these brothers were robbing banks. I can t imagine anything that would have made this film better. I give it 5 out of 5 Reels and I expect an Oscar nomination for the film. The brothers are classic anti-heroes in that they are making morally wrong choices, but still we see them as heroes because they are subverting the evil banking institution. They are chased by the virtuous (if albeit cantankerous) Rangers as anti-villains, trying to thwart the brothers  goal of robbing the bank. In the end Tanner martyrs himself, which is a selfless act, but kills Ranger Parker in the process, cementing his anti-hero status. I give this hero structure 5 out of 5 Heroes. We re witness to some fine mentoring by the venerable Ranger Hamilton upon the younger Ranger Parker. Although Hamilton insults Parker, he lets us know that it s a friendly way of acknowledging and (in a strange way) respecting their differences. We also see cross-mentoring between brothers Toby and Tanner. Tanner advises Toby in the ways of bank robbing while Toby shares his intelligence and values with Tanner. It s wonderful mentoring throughout which I award 5 out of 5 Mentor points.  Movie:  Mentor:  Heroes: 

SCOTT: Ditto, ditto, ditto, Greg. By hell or high water, this movie had better garner some Academy Award nominations. This film is a true cinematic achievement and boasts the complete package -- a meaty script, memorable characters, marvelous acting, a socially relevant message, and a surprising twist or two in the closing act. Jeff Bridges is especially brilliant; I ll never forget his complex emotional reaction after his successful sniping of his prey. I have no hesitation in awarding the film the full 5 Reels out of 5 here. Our four main characters represent the finest combination of heroes and anti-heroes we ve seen in the movies in several years. As you ve noted, Greg, each pairing has its own unique dynamic of power, influence, and communication. The Howard brothers have a lifetime of chemistry to draw from, and the Rangers are in the process of developing theirs. In the end, there is an unshakeable bond within each pairing, and it s a true tragedy that only one of the four walks away the rubble of this tragic story. For giving us fabulous characters with moral complexity whom we can really sink our analytic teeth into, this ensemble easily merits a rating of 5 Heroes out of 5. We ve talked at length about the complex and nuanced mentoring that goes on within each buddy hero and anti-hero pairing. We re also treated to a rare episode of anti-mentoring going on between Toby and his son. The father-son relationship is actually the catalytic epicenter of the entire robbery spree. As with everything else in this film, the mentoring is exceptionally interesting and warrants a rating of the full 5 Mentors out of 5. Movie:  Mentor:  Heroes:
